text: Ted Audio Collective It's Ted Talks, Ailey. I'm your host, Elise Hugh. The unsung heroes of congested urban areas are motorcycle cab drivers. And Lagos, they're the ones getting millions to work and other places they need to go. But their vehicles are powered by dirty, high polluting fuels. In his Ted 2022 talk, Otter Tio Bommi Duro shares his work to take these vehicles electric and transform the lives and livelihoods of drivers along the way. After the break. I join you from Lagos, Nigeria, one of the larger cities in Africa. By 2050, Lagos will outgrow many of the larger cities in the world, including New York and Mexico City. And will be home to over 32 million people. By that same date, Nigeria will be home to more people than the United States. But there is a problem. Lagos and other African-Megas cities suffer or are plagued by limited road infrastructure, pollution, congestion and poor city conditions. This makes it very difficult for people to get to work, especially in low-income communities, where poverty infrastructure gaps are pervasive. Enter the African motorcycle taxi driver. Driving on two and three wheels, they reach through the congested streets of Africa, getting people and goods to where they need to be. Unfortunately, these drivers are excluded from the formal economy. Unable to afford to buy clean, efficient vehicles, they are left to rent old gas engines from exploitative loan sharks. Because of this tough situation that these drivers endure, they are often left to friend for themselves. Part of what they also endure and suffer is high costs of operations from these exploitative loan sharks. And also, these drivers pollute the environment. If nothing is done, pollution from two and three wheels vehicles in Africa will hit 1.7 gigatons of emissions every year according to our estimates. This is equivalent to pollution from two million Boeing 737 airplanes every single year. I left my engineering job in 2013 to go to MIT where I met my co-founder, Cheney Duazador, a fellow engineer with similar dreams. We bonded about the realization that Africa was being left behind in the global transition to clean mobility. Inspired by the work of other innovators around the world, we chose to embark on a journey to create a three-part solution, which provides motorcycle taxi drivers in Africa access to electric vehicles, battery swaps and maintenance, and also emergency assistance. Here is how it works. Drivers sign up on the platform and instantly they get access to an electric motorcycle and a full battery swap. So therefore, they are able to save up and earn money to buy those vehicles. In addition, we also help lower their risks by providing them access to emergency response, health insurance, and maintenance plans. This represents an integrated approach to the design, manufacturing, financing, and operations of an electric mobility platform, targeted at highly vulnerable, informal, and on-banked people groups. The revenue from the drivers covers the cost of the electric fleet and the batteries, while the cost of R&D and technology is covered by our partners, including foundations, nonprofits, and investors. Meet Baba Gmeru, one of our drivers. Before signing up on our platform, he was a small holder farmer earning $3 a day in the Bamboo Bamboo community in southwestern Nigeria. Try that this stroke when Baba Gmeru lost his first son. Without help, he struggled to transport from produce, and therefore could not make ends meet. After signing up on our platform, he immediately got access to an electric motorcycle plus a fully charged battery on a daily basis. This enabled him to be able to transport people in his community, make a little bit more money, and also meet his obligations, including sending his younger son to school. Our platform enabled him to increase his net income on a daily basis from $3 to $6. Today, our platform has served a network of over 15,000 drivers, and our data shows that the average driver has about 5 dependents, meaning that our work has likely impacted over 75,000 livelihoods. By 2025, our goal is to provide electric mobility solutions to over 150,000 drivers. And if this idea really takes off, electric mobility innovators and climate entrepreneurs in Africa could jointly impact over 10 million motorcycle taxi drivers. By doing this, we will be helping to move the world's youngest and fastest growing continent towards a more sustainable and a prosperous future, and we will be creating jobs and reducing emissions. Thank you very much. For millennia, we have debated the link between our mental, physical, and spiritual health. So where are we now? We're going to have major breakthroughs in the ability to integrate the whole mind. What does consenting look feel and sound like for me, and how do I recognize that in other people? I think of it as energy. Are we amplifying our energy? Are we diminishing our energy? Mind body spirit, a three-part series on the Ted Radio Hour from NPR. Listen wherever you get your podcasts. Ted Talks daily is hosted by me, Elise Hugh, and produced by Ted. The music is from Alison Layton Brown, and our mixer is Christopher Faisy-Bogan. We record the talks at Ted Events We Host, or from Ted X Events, which are organized independently by volunteers all over the world. And we'd love to hear from you. Leave us a review on Apple podcasts or email us at podcasts at Ted.com. PRX.
